{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3007073,"name":"Stephen Le Viet","username":"StephenLe8714","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/e9bcb4/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-02-13T16:41:28.821Z","cooked":"

Hi! I have several questions on the ADSRX450 gyro.
I want to turn the robot to a set heading, but I don’t really understand the below code.

gyroscope1078×813 32.8 KB

(This image is from WPILib: Gyroscopes - Software — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation)

I think we can only input values from -1 to 1 for tankDrive; however, the code above conflicts with my assumption.
Also, could you explain why we have kP = 1 and how can I tune that number to fit my robot, please?

Thank you,
Stephen.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2022-02-13T16:42:50.529Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":234,"reads":72,"readers_count":71,"score":1184.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":402925,"topic_slug":"turning-to-a-set-heading-using-adsrx450-gyro","display_username":"Stephen Le Viet","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/hardware-apis/sensors/gyros-software.html?highlight=gyroscope","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Gyroscopes - Software — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":5},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/3/e/3e86f1f098b12eee8af8dadd1be9c5bbd14a1bbc.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50119,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/turning-to-a-set-heading-using-adsrx450-gyro/402925/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3007137,"name":"","username":"Berkeli","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/ba8739/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-02-13T19:15:25.164Z","cooked":"

So the idea is that you want to slow down the robot’s turn as you get to the set angle so it doesn’t overshoot.

The tankDrive method writes to the motor controller’s set(double percentage) method, which is capped at 1; any value above 1 will simply give a value of 1.
The error is the difference between the setpoint (90 degrees) and the current angle.

To tune KP, use SmartDashboard.putNumber("turn kP", kP); after the variable definition. Then put down kP = SmartDashboard.getNumber("turn kP", 0); in the autonomousPeriodic function.

Now when you enable the robot, you can tune kP by changing the value on the dashboard. Start at 0 and slowly tune it up each time until you get a nice response.

That said, you can be a little bit faster to make the turn using a full PID controller. I have attached an example of this.

image1289×834 56.8 KB

Let’s break this down a bit.
We set the PID constants in the code. We also put down the setpoint value (our goal angle).
Now we create a PID controller with the terms. Wikipedia has a fairly good article on the math behind PID controllers.
We want the robot to turn to the closest value, so we tell it that the inputs loop around the 180, -180 range. The idea is that if the robot is at 350 degrees and we want to turn to 0 degrees, we should turn 10 degrees left instead of 350 degrees right.
Now we set the tolerance. The first value is the amount of error in degrees you will allow, and the second is the maximum rate at that point. These affect when the atSetpoint() method returns true.

Down in the autonomousPeriodic method, we initialize the PID controller. This is because the setpoint defaults to 0 as does the input, so atSetpoint() will initially return true unless the PID controller has been run.

Then, we only try to turn if we are not already at the setpoint, and then we drive using the calculated value from the PID controller based on the current angle and our setpoint.

WPILib’s documentation on PID is pretty good: PID Control in WPILib — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

PID controllers are a bit harder to tune, but you can make them turn faster by increasing kP and stop instantly by increasing KD. For PID constants, a little goes a long way. Using 1 for kP is far too responsive. The image above has values that worked for our robot; they probably won’t be right for your robot, but yours will be closer to ours than to 1.

The FRC zero to autonomous series is really good on this. They show an example of using a PID controller to drive a distance; the code for turning is pretty similar. Here’s a link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jIKBWO7ps0w

Good luck!

Thank you so much for your detailed explanation!

Hi @Berkeli! Thank you so much for your explanation, but I still have some questions.

  1. How do you determine the second value when you set the tolerance?
  2. What if the angle gets bigger than 180 degrees or smaller than -180 degrees?

Thank you,
Stephen.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2022-02-14T00:47:52.321Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":37,"readers_count":36,"score":12.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":402925,"topic_slug":"turning-to-a-set-heading-using-adsrx450-gyro","display_username":"Stephen Le Viet","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50125,"username":"Berkeli","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/ba8739/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50119,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/turning-to-a-set-heading-using-adsrx450-gyro/402925/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3007263,"name":"","username":"Berkeli","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/ba8739/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-02-14T01:13:49.247Z","cooked":"
  1. The second value is how fast the robot’s heading can be changing. So if the robot is swinging by the setpoint really fast, you don’t want it to return true. In general higher values will make it more accurate but slower to line up and lower values will make it faster to finish lining up but less accurate. My team just does trial and error until we get a value that works. A fairly low value (less than 10) should be good. This value should need a lot less tuning than the P and D terms.
  2. If the angle gets bigger than 180 degrees, the code treats it as if it is now -180 degrees. So 181 is now -179, and -181 is 179 degrees.
    Hope this makes sense!
